titleStmt.title: Discretionary Prosecutorial Decision Making: Gender, Sexual Orientation, and Bias in Intimate Partner Violence

affiliation.orgName: Department of Criminology and Criminal Justice
Tess M.S. Neal, School of Social & Behavioral Sciences
Tess M.S. Neal, School of Social & Behavioral Sciences
Tess M.S. Neal, School of Social & Behavioral Sciences
Tess M.S. Neal, School of Social & Behavioral Sciences

analytic.title: Discretionary Prosecutorial Decision Making: Gender, Sexual Orientation, and Bias in Intimate Partner Violence

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Prosecutors exercise substantial discretion within the criminal justice process, potentially allowing for discrepant treatment of criminal cases. The purpose of this research was to examine the association between prosecutorial implicit biases and victim gender and sexual orientation in an intimate partner violence (IPV) case. Participants, 201 prosecutors from across the United States, completed two Implicit Association Tests to measure implicit gender attitudes and implicit attitudes regarding lesbian, gay, bisexual, and queer individuals. Participants were randomly assigned to one of four conditions (opposite-sex couple/female victim, opposite-sex couple/male victim, same-sex couple/female victim, same-sex couple/male victim) and read a case file of an alleged IPV arrest. Consistent with our hypotheses, prosecutors were 65% more likely to prosecute under the severest criminal penalty when the victim was female or included an opposite-sex couple. However, we found no evidence that implicit biases related to prosecutorial decisions.

div.p: The United States' legal system necessarily allows prosecutors substantial discretion when determining how to proceed with criminal charges (O'Neill, 2004). Many jurisdictions allow these "gatekeepers of the criminal justice system" (Jacoby & Ratledge, 2016) decision making power at multiple stages of criminal case processing, including the discretion to determine what criminal charges to apply following an arrest, how to proceed with plea bargain negotiations, trial strategy, and in some jurisdictions, sentencing recommendations. This discretion, however, may allow individual biases, including implicit biases, to influence prosecutorial case processing.

Implicit biases are associations between a social concept (e.g., male) and an evaluation (e.g., good, powerful) identified via indirect measurement (Greenwald & Lai, 2020). Two such biases, the implicit gender role bias and the implicit bias regarding lesbian, gay, bisexual, and queer individuals (LGBQ), may become particularly salient in criminal cases involving nontraditional gender role behavior and/or same-sex couples. Criminal cases of intimate partner violence (IPV), which involve coercion, dominance, and isolation in the context of an intimate relationship (Jackson, 2007), may represent such a situation -particularly when the intimate relationship involves a same-sex couple or male victim. Despite the vast literature on unconscious biases (see Greenwald et al., 2015;Oswald et al., 2015), to date, there is a dearth of research concerning implicit biases within the context of judicial decision making (see Kang et al., 2012). Further, while acknowledging the extensive literature concerning prosecutor charging decisions, particularly in cases of sexual assault (see The current study had two objectives: (a) examine how prosecutors consider the gender and sexual orientation of the defendant/victim dyad in a case of alleged IPV, and (b) determine if prosecutor implicit biases predict discretionary decision making in a case of alleged IPV.

div.head: Prosecutorial Decision Making
div.p: Legal scholars and criminologists have studied prosecutorial discretion for decades (Kerstetter, 1990;McDonald, 1979). More recently, public discourse and popular media have focused on the power of this group at multiple stages of criminal case processing. As noted by O'Neill (2004), some level of discretion is necessary at both the state and federal levels.
Constraints on resources make it impossible for prosecutors to pursue every case, and differences in legal statutes and regional priorities make mandatory prosecution impossible.

Despite the considerable control prosecutors exercise over the criminal justice process, when compared to other decision making groups (e.g., juries), research with this population is relatively sparse, typically non-empirical, and has generally focused on a single decision point (i.e., plea bargaining; see Redlich et al., 2017) or case type (i.e., sexual assault; see Sphon & Tellis, 2014). One major research focus concerns the legal (e.g., evidentiary factors) and extralegal (e.g., defendant race, economic class) factors that relate to prosecutorial discretion.

Regarding extralegal factors, some non-experimental studies suggest defendant race may be related to charging decisions (Kaiser, et al., 2017;Petersen, 2017). However, experimental research has failed to identify such effects in the laboratory, suggesting disparities frequently observed in non-experimental settings may be driven by other unknown factors (Robertson et al., 2019). Instead of focusing solely on legal (or extralegal) factors, it is likely that prosecutors consider some combination of both (Kutateladze et al., 2014;Wu, 2016). For example, employing a mixed-method design, Frederick and Stemen (2012) concluded prosecutorial decisions were driven by two basic questions, a) can I prove this case? and b) should I prove this case? When determining if one can prove the case, both legal and extralegal factors may be considered. For example, prosecutors likely evaluate the strength of the available evidence (legal factor) and victim socioeconomic status (extralegal factor). Unsurprisingly, prosecutors are more likely to move forward with prosecution when they perceive evidence to be strong and the likelihood of a conviction to be high (Frohmann, 1991).

According to Frederick and Stemen (2012), the factors considered when deciding whether one should pursue a case are typically extralegal such as the characteristics of the defendant/victim. Although seemingly objective, this allows room for bias, often in fairly complex ways. For example, a prosecutor may perceive injuries sustained from sexual assault as less serious when the victim is male, particularly if the victim implicates a female aggressor. It is possible implicit biases act as extralegal factors in that they are associated with the prosecutor perceiving a crime to be less egregious and subsequently less willing to allocate resources to prosecution. We know of no research that has examined how IPV dyad sexual orientation and gender interact with prosecutor biases to influence this discretionary decision making.

div.head: Differential Treatment of Men and Women
div.p: An individual's sex is biologically determined and refers to the individual's reproductive system and secondary sex characteristics. This is differentiated from gender (i.e., masculinity and femininity), which includes a set of socially and culturally prescribed behaviors, traits, and patterns of interpersonal interaction based on sex. While sex is typically considered binary (i.e., F o r P e e r R e v i e w male, female), gender exists on a continuum and can change over time. As Renzetti and colleagues (2012) note, in certain contexts the degree to which an individual identifies with masculine or feminine traits is perhaps less important than the extent to which others perceive these traits to apply and behave in ways to reinforce these assumptions. As such, for the purposes of the current research, we intentionally use the label "gender" to describe manipulations between conditions.

Despite the criminal justice system's core principle that defendants are treated equally, social science research consistently suggests this doctrine is not upheld (see, Tonry, 2015) and a large body of research concerns the differential treatment of men and women. In general, the research regarding sentencing suggests that female offenders are treated less punitively than their male counterparts (Ahola et al., 2009;Spohn & Beichner, 2000), even when controlling for the type of offense and the criminal history of the offender (e.g., Spohn, 1999). However, the type of crime and characteristics of the victim may interact with defendant gender to influence sentencing decisions (Fernando Rodriguez et al., 2006). For example, Curry and colleagues (2004) analyzed Texas conviction and sentencing data for three specific violent crimes and concluded victim gender interacts with defendant gender to predict sentencing, such that male offenders received longer sentence lengths when the victim was female.

div.head: Prosecutorial Decision Making in IPV Cases
div.p: Historical conceptualizations of IPV are highly gendered and the criminal justice system typically reflected the framework of the male abuser and female victim. Thus, it is unsurprising that men are far more likely to be arrested for IPV (National Coalition Against Domestic Violence, 2020). There is also preliminary evidence to indicate that prosecutors are unlikely to deny prosecution for male-perpetrated IPV (Lantz, 2020). For example, MacNeil and colleagues F o r P e e r R e v i e w (2020) manipulated the gender of the IPV defendant and found prosecutors recommended punitive criminal charges and a more punitive plea deal when the defendant was male. However, this leniency may depend on the severity of the incident and differences in jurisdictional statutes (see Cox et al., in press, for a review).

Only one empirical study has considered prosecutorial decision making and defendant/victim gender. Cox and colleagues (2021) manipulated the gender and sexual orientation of a defendant victim dyad for a case of alleged IPV, effectively creating four conditions: opposite-sex couple/male aggressor, opposite-sex couple/female aggressor, same-sex couple/male aggressor, same-sex couple/female aggressor. A total of 107 prosecutors from across the United States responded to a vignette describing the alleged IPV incident, including witness statements and victim injuries. The researchers reported no differences between conditions regarding prosecutor willingness to proceed with criminal charges or the severity of the applied criminal statute and concluded prosecutorial decision making in IPV cases may not be unduly influenced by the dyad's gender or sexual orientation -at least, not in a laboratory vignette context.

div.head: Implicit and Explicit Gender Role Attitudes
div.p: The majority of studies that have examined judgements about criminal behaviors have focused on the decision makers' demographic factors such as gender and race. Herzog and Oreg (2008) argue that this sociological approach is lacking because it does not consider individual differences. Specifically, focusing on group affiliation assumes all members of that group hold the same attitudes and biases, an assumption that is likely short sighted. Alternatively, individual values and beliefs may provide a more nuanced understanding of any disparate treatment. (Stanziani et al., 2020). Recent research has also considered how implicit biases may impact individual decision making and behaviors. Implicit biases are driven by attitudes and stereotypes that an individual holds about social categories such as gender, sex, and sexual orientation. These biases are measured indirectly and not always consistent with an individual's expressed beliefs (Greenwald & Lai, 2020). Implicit attitudes may influence how an individual a) behaves toward the reference group and b) interprets data -two tasks crucial for prosecutorial decision making. Research exploring how these biases are at play within the criminal justice context is sorely needed.

div.head: Intimate Partner Violence and the LGBQ Community
div.p: Lay perceptions of IPV include the belief that this violence is highly gendered and the law is inclined to reinforce this belief. For example, the strongest legal protections against IPV come from the Violence Against Women Act; similarly, federal and private funding organizations discuss leading factors of IPV using primarily gendered and heteronormative vocabulary. However, IPV is pervasive and impactful throughout American culture.

Approximately 36% of women and 33% of men will experience sexual violence, physical violence, or stalking by an intimate partner in their lifetime (Smith et al., 2018). Further, victims of IPV report significant and chronic mental and physical health conditions (Coker et al., 2002), and estimates suggest the economic impact of IPV on U.S. society exceeds $6 billion annually (Max et al., 2004).

Members of the LGBQ community may be particularly vulnerable; lifetime prevalence rates for LGBQ identified individuals are equal to or higher than their non-LGBQ counterparts (NCAVP, 2015). For example, Langenderfer-Magruder and colleagues (2016) reported 26-33% Importantly, gender role expectations and conflict may be one causal factor for IPV in this population. For example, Woodyatt and Stephenson (2016) conducted focus groups with gay and bisexual men and found, within the context of same-sex relationships, emotional violence was driven by gender roles, power differentials, and internalized homophobia. Further, Oringher and Samuelson (2011) determined men in same-sex relationships who perpetrated IPV were more likely to conform to traditional gender norms. The significance of gender roles is not limited to male same-sex relationships; Sanger and Lynch (2017) explored gendered scripts in lesbian and bisexual women's relationship accounts and also highlighted the salience of heterogendered norms for IPV.

Despite the rates of IPV within these same-sex couples, recent research suggests the legal system may treat same-sex IPV differently. Legislation typically neglects same-sex victims of IPV (Ahmed & Jindasurat, 2014) and police are less likely to intervene in same-sex abuse cases (Peterman & Dixon, 2003). Further, legal protections and social services are greatly reduced for this population (Samons, 2012). At the trial level, however, observable differences in treatment are more ambiguous. Seelau and colleagues (2003) presented mock jurors with a summary of an IPV incident and manipulated the genders of the perpetrator and victim. Violence against a female, regardless of the perpetrator's gender, was perceived to be more serious and more in need of intervention. Other studies report similar findings (e.g., Sorenson & Thomas, 2009;Stanziani et al., 2018). Ahemn et al., (2013) and Stanziani et al., (2020) also found an interaction of gender and sexual orientation, such that the condition describing an opposite-sex F o r P e e r R e v i e w couple/female victim, was perceived to be most egregious. However, these perceptions may not translate into tangible criminal justice outcomes. Specifically, Stanziani and colleagues (2018) reported mock jurors were more confident in a guilty verdict when the defendant was male, regardless of victim gender. These conflicting results suggest more comprehensive research, particularly research examining individual differences, is necessary.

div.head: Current Study
div.p: Prosecutors have significant discretion when determining the most justifiable application of criminal statutes. However, the factors that influence prosecutorial decision making are relatively unknown. The current study examined the role of defendant/victim dyad gender and sexual orientation on prosecutorial decision making. Although previous research has considered these extralegal factors in juror decision making (e.g., Stanziani et al., 2018) relatively little is known regarding prosecutorial considerations of these factors. In addition, we were interested in the potential role of prosecutor implicit biases.

Hypotheses 1) When the couple includes a female victim, prosecutors will be more likely to seek a criminal indictment, prosecute under the most severe criminal charge, and choose the most punitive initial plea offer.

2) When the alleged IPV incident includes a same-sex couple, prosecutors will be less likely to seek a criminal indictment, prosecute under the least severe criminal charge, and choose the least punitive plea offer.

Drawing from previous research (Poorman et al., 2003;Stanziani et al., 2018) we formed hypotheses to examine the extent to which implicit traditional gender role bias and LGBQ bias interact with the independent variables to impact prosecutorial decision making. This study is part of a larger project preregistered with the Open Science Framework.

Only data and material pertinent to the present research question are included here. With the exception of the proprietary Implicit Association Tests (IAT), all study materials are accessible on the OSF platform (OSF Anonymized Link).

div.head: Method Participants
div.p: A power analysis for Chi-square Test of Independence was performed using the pwr2ppl package in R (Aberson, 2019). The power analysis indicated a sample size of at least 130 is necessary to detect small to medium effects (ES( ) = 0.30) with 0.80 power, two degrees of freedom (2x3 cross-tab) and alpha set at 0.025. For the 2x2 contingency tables, a minimum sample size of 105 is needed to detect small to medium effects.

Participant professional contact information was compiled into a large database from publicly available internet based sources. To develop the database, using the Google search engine, researchers searched for the following terms "District Attorney + State," "Prosecution + State," "Prosecutor + State." The term "state" was substituted for each of the 50 U.S. states.

Researchers were liberal in searching; these initial terms generally led to more specific searches (e.g., state bar association websites, county and city government websites). In addition, searches F o r P e e r R e v i e w were a continuous process to account for turnover in the prosecutor profession. For the current study, the database included searches completed in 2019-2020.

A solicitation email advertised the study as an investigation into prosecutorial decision making in a case of alleged intimate partner violence. Of the 6,497 solicitation emails sent, 505 people expressed interest in the study and subsequently received a web based link to complete the first portion of the study (i.e., Study Session 1). This link was accessed 316 times. However, participant data were removed if IAT values were incalculable due to too many participant errors (i.e., more than 30% of the participant's responses were incorrect pairings, n = 61), data were missing from the second portion of the study (i.e., Study Session two; n = 41), or the participant failed one of three manipulation checks (n = 13). working as a prosecutor. The majority of the sample identified as male (58.2%), White (90.5%), "straight" or heterosexual (94%) and married (70.1%; see Table 1 for comprehensive demographic information).

div.head: Procedures
div.p: All study procedures were consistent with relevant ethical guidelines regarding human subjects research and were approved by (redacted for peer review) Institutional Review Board.

Study procedures occurred online through the Project Implicit platform (https://implicit.harvard.edu/implicit/). Researchers sent short study solicitations directly to participant email addresses. If interested in participation, participants completed a brief questionnaire to ensure they met eligibility criteria. Three to days following session one, participants were contacted and prompted to complete session two. Participants first viewed the criminal investigation unit case summary, separate statements from the victim and defendant, and a medical note from the treating physician. Following this, participants reviewed standard criminal codes and completed the case appraisal form and manipulation checks. After completion of study two measures, participants were rerouted to a website where they had the option of receiving monetary compensation ($100 Amazon.com gift card) for their time.

div.head: Case file
div.p: Participants read a comprehensive case file which included a criminal investigation unit case summary, official statements given by the defendant and victim, and a medical report from the hospital physician who treated the victim. The case file specifies the defendant was arrested for Domestic Violence in the First Degree (Class A Felony). To increase ecological validity, these materials were created in consultation with a practicing district attorney and closely resembled information typically available to prosecutors at case onset. In addition, based on previous research exploring prosecutor decision making in IPV cases (Cox et al., 2021), the defendant and victim were described as similar physical sizes and the victim was characterized as "cooperative." Independent variables (i.e., defendant and victim sexual orientation and gender) were manipulated creating four conditions. The sexual orientation of the couple was made salient through victim self-identification via the victim statement and the gender of the defendant and victim was made salient through gender specific pronouns (e.g., he/she, his/hers) and gender typical names (e.g., Jessica/John, Jeremy/John, John/Jessica, Jessica/Julia). This created four experimental conditions: straight couple/female victim; straight couple/male victim; lesbian couple/female victim; gay couple/male victim.

div.head: Criminal Code Definitions
div.p: Considering jurisdictional variation in criminal codes, participants were provided with generic criminal code definitions including definitions for terms related to "Domestic Violence"

(as labeled by the criminal statute). In addition, participants reviewed the criteria for six criminal statutes (e.g., Class A Felony, Assault in the First degree; Class A Misdemeanor, Domestic violence in the Third degree).

div.head: Implicit Association Test (IAT)
div.p: The Implicit Association Test (IAT) is a popular remote task that purportedly measures the strength of association between concepts (e.g., race, gender), characterizations (weak, emotional), and valanced categories (e.g., good, bad). Proponents argue the IAT is a generally valid and reliable measure of individual implicit biases (Greenwald et al., 2015). However, of note, there is debate regarding the utility of the task outside of a laboratory context (Oswald et al., 2015).

Participants completed the Gender-Career IAT, Sexuality IAT, and one filler IAT (Disability IAT) randomly ordered. The Gender-Career IAT (herein referred to as the "gender IAT") measures the extent to which an individual associates females with family and males with career. Although not a perfect proxy for traditional gender role attitudes, previous research has used this IAT to assess gender bias (Endendijk et al., 2018) and it demonstrates moderate positive correlations with explicit gender-role stereotypes (Endendijk et al., 2013). The Sexuality IAT (herein referred to as the "LGBQ IAT") measures the extent to which an individual associates valenced words with LGBQ symbols and "straight" symbols. The filler IAT was included to decrease the likelihood that participants guessed the research questions.

div.head: Case Appraisal Form
div.p: A case appraisal form assessed dependent variables. Specifically, participants responded to a series of questions to ascertain their approach to case processing. This form included questions regarding proceeding with criminal charges ("Does the available evidence require you

div.head: Manipulation Questions
div.p: Participants responded to three questions designed to ensure the saliency of the manipulated variables. Specifically, participants indicated the gender of the alleged victim, the gender of the defendant, and their perception of the defendant's sexual orientation based on the case materials.

div.head: Data Analytic Plan
div.p: As per our preregistered data analytic plan, we conducted chi-square and logistic regression analyses, which is a variant of the generalized linear model that incorporates binary and ordinal dependent variables. We used binary logistic regressions for dichotomous outcomes (i.e., likelihood of proceeding with charges and offering a plea), and ordinal logistic regressions for ordinally-distributed outcomes (i.e., severity of charges and plea offered). For all logistic regression results, analyses were conducted in two steps: (1) main effects only (not shown) and

(2) both main effects and then interaction term (for the interaction hypotheses). The covariates were not included in each model after an examination of the bivariate relationship between the demographic measures and the experimental condition measure yielded nonsignificant results. To test hypotheses 1 and 2, chi-square tests of association were used. To test hypotheses 3 and 4, a series of binary and ordinal logistic regression analyses were run. In addition to reporting overall models, we also explore and report individual binary effects. Although this may increase the likelihood of Type 1 error via multiple comparisons in a family of tests, to address this, we readjusted the alpha level using the Bonferroni corrected alpha (p ≤ .025), to decrease the likelihood of a Type 1 error. All analyses were conducted in STATA 17. For some cells in the contingency tables, the expected and observed frequency is less than 5, thus, we used Fisher's exact test to determine significance.

div.head: Prosecution and Applicable Criminal Statutes
div.p: We hypothesized a main effect of victim gender, such that when the victim was female prosecutors would be more likely to seek a criminal indictment, prosecute under the most severe criminal charge, and choose the most punitive initial plea offer. Although victim gender was not significantly related to the binary decisions by prosecutors regarding whether they would proceed with criminal charges (χ 2 = 0.002, p = 0.588) or offer a plea bargain (χ 2 = 0.458, p = 0.334), victim gender was related to the ordinal judgments related to statute selection (χ 2 = 10.123, p = 0.006) and plea deal severity (χ 2 = 7.643, p = 0.011; see Table 2). Consistent in part with Hypothesis 1, victim gender was significantly associated with criminal statute severity such that, when the victim was female, 64.94% of prosecutors selected the most serious offense (see Table 2). Victim gender was also significantly related to plea offers in that, when the victim was female, the majority of prosecutors selected the most severe plea offer. Further, the Cramér's statistics for whether prosecutors proceed with charges or offer a plea bargain indicate weak associations with victim gender (see Table 2). However, the Cramér's statistic for statute selection and plea deal severity indicate moderate associations with victim gender. We also hypothesized a main effect of IPV dyad sexual orientation, in that we expected prosecutors would be less punitive (i.e., seek a criminal indictment, apply the severest criminal charge, etc.) when the IPV dyad included a same-sex couple (Table 3). In part consistent with Hypothesis 2, when the IPV dyad included an opposite-sex couple the majority of prosecutors (55.84%) selected the most severe charge (χ 2 = 7.551, p = 0.024). Finally, IPV dyad sexual orientation was not associated with prosecutors' decision regarding whether to proceed with charges (χ 2 = 0.281, p = 0.369), plea deal application (χ 2 = 0.741, p = 0.269), or severity of the plea offer (χ 2 = 2.606, p = 0.392). The Cramér's statistics for whether prosecutors proceed with charges, offer a plea bargain, and plea deal severity indicate weak associations with dyad sexual orientation. The Cramér's statistic for statute selection indicates moderate associations with dyad sexual orientation.

We hypothesized an interaction between prosecutor implicit gender role attitudes and victim gender (Hypothesis 3, Table 4). Specifically, we expected stronger implicit attitudes in favor of traditional gender roles to be associated with punitive decision making when the victim was female. As seen in Table 4 however, prosecutor Gender IAT scores did not interact with victim gender to predict decision to proceed (OR = 3.42, p = 0.568) or decision to offer a plea bargain (OR = 1.43, p = 0.848). Further, implicit gender attitudes did not interact with victim gender to predict charging decision (OR = 0.219, p = 0.534) or plea deal application (OR = 0.08, p = 0.129; see Table 4).

Hypothesis 4 concerned prosecutor implicit attitudes regarding sexual orientation (see Table 5). Specifically, we expected stronger negative LGBQ attitudes would be associated with punitive decision making in conditions with the opposite-sex IPV dyad. Contrary to our hypothesis, however, implicit LGBQ attitudes did not interact with couple sexual orientation to predict decision to proceed (OR = 0.50, p = 0.591) or decision to offer a plea bargain (OR = F o r P e e r R e v i e w 0.65, p = 0.690). In addition, no significant interaction of implicit LGBQ dyad sexual orientation emerged in predicting criminal charge severity (OR = 1.24, p = 0.743) or plea deal application (OR = 1.29, p = 0.748).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The purpose of this study was to explore the association between gender and sexual orientation, prosecutorial implicit biases, and decision making in a case of alleged IPV. We manipulated the gender and sexual orientation of the defendant/victim dyad to create four conditions, with one condition resembling "stereotypical IPV" (i.e., male defendant/female victim), and the remaining three conditions representing "atypical IPV." Overall, our findings were nonsignificant when focusing on binary decision outcomes. That is, victim gender and same-sex versus opposite-sex partnerships did not directly affect prosecutors' decisions about whether to seek a criminal indictment or offer a plea deal. However, when elements of this decision process were measured ordinally, the effects we expected did emerge. It is not unusual to find this pattern of outcomes in legal decision research: often direct effects of biasing influences on ultimate legal decisions are elusive even when indirect effects of these same biasing influences are found in earlier elements of the decision process (e.g., Neal & Cramer, 2017;Neal et al., 2012).

We found that victim gender impacted statutory decisions, such that prosecutors were 65% more likely to prosecute under the severest criminal penalty when the victim was female, regardless of the defendant's gender. Similarly, participants were 61.5% more likely to select the most severe plea deal when the victim was female, compared to the male victim. These results are somewhat consistent with Romain and Freiburger's (2016) correlational study, which examined IPV census data from one Midwestern county and determined female-on-female (their F o r P e e r R e v i e w characterization) cases were least likely to be dismissed. However, of note, Cox and colleagues (2021) reported different findings in a sample similar to the present study (i.e., U.S. prosecutors).

Specifically, these researchers reported victim gender did not impact charge severity or harshness of the plea bargain offered, although (consistent with current findings), there was also no impact of victim gender on decision to proceed with charges. Although both studies included samples of active U.S. prosecutors, discrepancies may be attributed to statistical power, with analyses in the current study likely higher powered, thus decreasing the likelihood of a Type II error. Further, it is possible this study's ecologically valid stimulus materials, relative to Cox et al., attributed to the reduction in differences between conditions. Specifically, participants in the Cox et al. study read a short vignette describing an alleged altercation between a same-sex or opposite-sex couple. In contrast, participants in the current study read an entire (fictional) case file including police reports, defendant and victim statements, and medical records. Perhaps with comprehensive information, prosecutor participants engaged in more critical thinking and focused more acutely on the relevant legal factors.

The impact of sexual orientation was similarly mixed. Specifically, there was a significant main effect of sexual orientation, with participants approximately 51% more likely to select the most severe criminal charge when the dyad included an opposite-sex couple as compared to a same-sex couple. Again, this is inconsistent with findings originally reported by Cox et al. (2021), who reported no association between IPV dyad sexual orientation charging decision. However, IPV dyad sexual orientation did not impact binary decisions regarding proceeding with criminal charges or offering a plea deal and additional research may elucidate these discrepancies. The main effect models suggest these manipulated variables may not impact larger, more substantial decisions (e.g., does the evidence and facts of the case necessitate that the prosecutor proceeds with criminal charges?). Instead, it is possible these factors play a role in more nuanced questions or in earlier judgments that make up the ultimate decision process, when the discretion of the prosecutor is less likely to be questioned. Thus, this is consistent with Frederick and Stemen's (2012) distinction between when a prosecutor can prove a case versus when a prosecutor should prove a case. Across all conditions the evidence (legal factor) remained identical and prosecutor participants generally believed they can prove the case. However, the extralegal factors (sexual orientation and gender) may have influenced whether the prosecutor participants believed that they should prove the case.

Prosecutorial decision making is cumulative, with decisions made at initial points (e.g., what criminal statute to apply when determining initial charges) impacting later decision (e.g., leniency of plea offer; Kutateladze et al., 2014). For example, there is ample evidence of an association between pretrial detention and guilty pleas, with those individuals who are held pretrial, either through court-mandated remand or failure to pay the court imposed bond, more likely to plead guilty and to plead guilty faster than their counterparts awaiting trial in the community (Heaton et al., 2017). The concept of "cumulative-disadvantage" (Scherr et al., 2020) is gaining favor in legal decision making research and may be one mechanism to understanding more general disparities in criminal justice outcomes.

In addition to examining any main effects of manipulated variables, a primary objective of this research program was to understand if prosecutorial implicit biases, as measured by the IAT, impacted discretionary decision making. On the whole, hypotheses were unsupported.

Specifically, there were no relationships between prosecutor gender attitudes IAT scores and F o r P e e r R e v i e w outcome variables, or prosecutor LGBQ attitudes and outcome variables. Further, IAT scores did not interact with any of the manipulated variables. There are several potential explanations for these null findings. First, it is entirely possible that the broad construct of prosecutorial unconscious biases are not applicable in this experimental context. Prosecutorial decision making is not automatic; it is a complex process influenced by a myriad of legal and extra-legal factors (see Jacoby & Ratledge, 2016). As noted by Monteith and colleagues (2002) prejudice reduction is highly dependent on the individual's ability to monitor their response and consider how this response is consistent with egalitarian goals. Specifically, deliberative decision making can allow an individual to actively engage in bias detection and subsequently override associations (Greenwald & Banaji, 2017). It is possible that in this experimental context, prosecutorparticipants were actively monitoring themselves in an attempt to control and minimize bias in their responses. This finding is consistent with other studies with actual professionals that failed to find evidence of bias in the experimental context even when there is clear evidence of disparate outcomes in the real world (e.g., Robertson et al., 2019).

Second, it is possible unconscious biases are related to prosecutorial decision making but the IAT does not capture these associations within this context. There is some debate regarding the utility of the IAT. For example, Oswald and colleagues (2015) argue the IAT demonstrates little predictive validity in real-world settings and Blanton et al., (2015) proffer there is sparse evidence to indicate the IAT predicts tangible behavioral outcomes. Despite this criticism, there are published data indicating the IAT can be a valid measure of implicit association in "the field" (Carnes et al., 2016;Onyeader et al., 2020) and, although other measures of implicit associations exist (e.g., Affect Misattribution Procedure, Payne et al., 2005 And yet, the extent to which the IAT can inform the social cognitive processes of legal decision making remains unclear. Further, the specific IATs applied in this research are relatively understudied when compared to the race IAT, which enjoys considerable popularity (Oswald et al., 2013). Relatedly, consistent with previous research (e.g., Endendijk et al., 2013), we employed the Gender IAT as a proxy for implicit gender role biases. However, this IAT measures the association between gender and stereotypically gendered careers. Thus, it is possible an imperfect measure of the underlying construct hindered detection of any notable effects. Consistent with Oswald and colleagues' (2013) suggestion, future IAT research should consider measuring and statistically controlling for potential confounding variables (e.g., working memory). Further, future research with this population may consider if a different measure of implicit bias demonstrates predictive validity in a psycholegal context.
Broadly, the data from this experimental research are promising; the IPV dyad sex and sexual orientation did not impact prosecutors' decisions to charge or enter into plea negotiations.

Further, prosecutor implicit biases regarding gender and sexual orientation were not significantly associated with decision making. Important effects did emerge regarding victim gender in that, consistent with previous research regarding mock juries (see Devine, 2012), prosecutors were more punitive when working with a female victim.

div.head: Limitations and Future Directions
div.p: Although many non-empirical studies have examined prosecutorial discretion, there is a dearth of experimental research regarding prosecutorial decision making and criminal case processing. As such, more methodologically rigorous research has the potential to advance our understanding of the legal and extralegal factors associated with prosecutorial discretion. As Participants were recruited via email solicitations using publically available email addresses as well as via "snowballing" sampling in that participants were asked to forward the solicitation to other potentially interested individuals. The response rate (~3% of those contacted participated in the study) is somewhat lower than those reported previously with a similar population and methodological approach (e.g., ~9%; Cox et al., 2021). The reason for this low response rate it not immediately clear but may be partiality attributed to the task burden (approximately two hours over two sessions). Further, many prosecutors solicited for participation informed researchers their area of specialization (e.g., prosecuting homicide or financial crimes) fell outside of IPV and they declined to participate because they had little or no experience prosecuting these cases. Indeed, many larger jurisdictions have specialized prosecution "units" with prosecutors focusing on specific criminal areas. Thus, while the low response rate could suggest limited generalizability, it is also possible that the prosecutors who participated are more likely to actually practice in this area.

Data from the current study suggest prosecutor IAT scores are not associated with IPV case processing decisions. However, as noted above, some have questioned the utility of the IAT outside of the laboratory. Although disparate treatment within the criminal justice system is well established, future studies should consider how implicit biases may contribute to inequities and whether the IAT is a useful tool in detecting any association.

Female racial and ethnic minorities, particularly Black women, experience IPV at disproportionally higher rates and are more likely to be murdered by an intimate partner than F o r P e e r R e v i e w their White women counterparts (Stockman, et al., 2015). Further, there is some data to suggest women of color are less likely to receive charge reductions in IPV cases (Romain & Freiburger, 2016). The study of the intersectionality of gender and race is important and necessary. Although the current study did not specify the racial or ethnic identity of the IPV dyad, the racial stereotypes of the names (Conaway & Bethune, 2015), as well as White normativity, may have resulted in participants making an assumption of the dyad's Whiteness. As such, the extent to which these findings generalize to people of color, particularly queer people of color, is unknown.

Finally, prosecutorial decision-making is cumulative, with later considerations relying on previous decisions (Kutateladze et al., 2014). And in most jurisdictions, prosecutorial offices and police agencies are a loosely coupled system (Petersen, 2017); acting independently but relying significantly on the corresponding agency (Harris, 2011;Orton & Weick, 1990). As such, any investigations into plea bargain offers or trial strategy are incomplete without consideration of earlier decision points including officer investigation and arrest.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Although disparate legal and criminal justice outcomes are well-established, the reasons for such discrepancies require additional study. We found evidence of discretionary prosecutorial bias related to victim gender and LGBQ-status of IPV dyad, but only in ordinally-measured variables involved in elements of prosecutors' decision processes. We found no evidence of bias in ultimate charging or plea-offering decisions by prosecutors and no evidence of implicit bias affecting these decisions. As such, it appears IPV dyad sexual orientation and IPV victim gender is potentially associated with differential decision making, although the impact and interpretation of this association is nuanced. Although informative, these data raise additional questions about LGBT IAT X Dyad Sexual Orientation interaction term. OR = Odds ratio, SE = standard error, 95% C.I. = 95% confidence interval

The final sample included 201 prosecutors working throughout the United States. The sample resembled the active U.S. prosecutor population (Reflective Democracy Campaign, 2015), with an average age of 41.49 (SD = 9.97) and an average of 10.25 years (SD = 8.43)

Study session one consisted of a demographic questionnaire including information pertinent to the participants' legal practice, such as primary jurisdiction of practice, years of practice, and approximate number of cases closed each year. Participants also completed three self-report questionnaires that are not the focus of this manuscript. Finally, participants completed three counterbalanced Implicit Association Tests.

The IAT includes five stages, (a) Stage 1, initial target-concept discrimination (woman vs. man), (b) Stage 2, initial evaluative attribute discrimination (beautiful vs. nasty), (c) Stage 3, initial combined task (woman + beautiful vs. man + nasty), (d) Stage 4, reversed target-concept discrimination (man vs. women), and (e) Stage 5, reverse combined task (woman + nasty vs. man + beautiful). Consistent with Greenwald et al.'s, (2003) recommendation, participant scores ("D" values) were determined by calculating the scaled estimated difference in mean reaction times in stages three and five. D values range from -2.0 (strong negative association) to 2.0 (strong positive association). For example, a D value of +1.8 indicates a relatively strong association between the Target A + Positive Attribute; Target B + Negative Attribute (e.g., women beautiful; men nasty) while D value of -1.8 indicates a relatively strong association between Target A + Negative Attribute; Target B + Positive Attribute (e.g., woman nasty; man beautiful).

Participants also indicated if they would pursue a plea deal and what charge to offer as a plea ("Which of the following most closely resembles the plea offer you would open with? 1) Domestic Violence -Second Degree, Class B Felony, six months in jail, 2) Domestic Violence -Third Degree, Class A Misdemeanor, $1000 fine, six months' probation, 3) Disorderly Conduct -Class A Misdemanor, $1000 fine").
